author: BBC News
title: Northern Lights dazzle across North East and Cumbria
text:
The Northern Lights have once again been visible across large swathes of north-east England and Cumbria.
According to BBC Weather, it was the strongest and most widespread show of lights in the UK since May.
The phenomenon, also known as aurora borealis, occurs when charged particles from the Sun collide with gases in the Earth's atmosphere around the magnetic poles. Scientists have likened it to "a big sneeze by the Sun" .
As the particles collide with the gases, light is emitted at various wavelengths, creating colourful displays in the sky.
People from across the region sent images to the BBC.
Holy Island, at Northumberland, saw particularly vivid skies, while the Lake District was another spot for dramatic illuminations.
PA Media The refuge hut on the causeway leading to Holy Island, Northumberland Mark Hetherington Warnscale Bothy in Buttermere, Cumbria Ian McClelland Newbottle, Sunderland PA Media Holy Island, Northumberland Daphne Eddington Braithwaite, Cumbria Mark Hetherington Tewet Tarn near Keswick, Cumbria Jonathan Kellager Cullercoats, North Tyneside Nigel Craig Threlkeld, Cumbria Carolyn Farthing-Dunn Shotley Bridge, County Durham B Dabbous Yarm, Stockton-on-Tees Follow BBC North East on X and Facebook and BBC Cumbria on X and Facebook and both on Nextdoor and Instagram . Send your story ideas to northeastandcumbria@bbc.co.uk.
More on this topic What are the Northern Lights?

author: TyC Sports.com
title: Inesperado conflicto entre MatÃ­as Rojas y Corinthians, a meses de su llegada - TyC Sports
text: MatÃ­as Rojas podrÃ­a demandar a Corinthians e irse libre El atacante paraguayo, que llegÃ³ al Timao a mediados de este aÃ±o, amenaza con declararse en libertad de acciÃ³n si los brasileÃ±os no regularizan su situaciÃ³n. A menos de seis meses de su llegada al Corinthians, MatÃ­as Rojas se encuentra en conflicto con el club de Brasil y podrÃ­a declararse en libertad de acciÃ³n si el Timao no se pone al dÃ­a con una deuda que tiene para con el futbolista paraguayo. SegÃºn la prensa brasileÃ±a, la cifra que le debe el club al 10 ronda el millÃ³n de dÃ³lares. Rojas, que en julio firmÃ³ como futbolista libre con Corinthians tras el final de su vÃ­nculo con Racing, intimÃ³ a su club por un atraso en el pago de su salario y dinero por derechos de imagen. En este contexto, el aviso del futbolista fue que le darÃ­a al club brasileÃ±o una semana de plazo para que se regularice la situaciÃ³n. En caso de que el Timao no le pague lo que le corresponda a Rojas, el exLanÃºs, Defensa y Racing se asumirÃ¡ como jugador libre y podrÃ­a firmar un nuevo vÃ­nculo con cualquier club del mundo, ademÃ¡s de exigirle a Corinthians el pago de su contrato, que habÃ­a sido firmado hasta finales de 2026. Desde que llegÃ³ a Corinthians, Rojas disputÃ³ 20 partidos en los que aportÃ³ dos asistencias y no pudo festejar todavÃ­a su primer gol. El paraguayo es uno de los futbolistas mejores pagos del plantel y Corinthians se encuentra en una transiciÃ³n polÃ­tica, con un presidente prÃ³ximo a asumir en los primeros dÃ­as de 2024. Â¿Le buscarÃ¡n una salida rÃ¡pida? No te pierdas nada

author: Ximena Bustillo
title: Climate hasn't been core to the GOP. These conservatives are trying to change that
text: Climate hasn't been core to the GOP. These conservatives are trying to change that Tucked into a hallway at the Republican National Convention, between booths promoting the Second Amendment and another selling official merchandise of the Trump Campaign, sat a sprawling display of the conservative legacy in environmentalism. Young conservatives ran back and forth asking convention goers with Nixon pins if they were familiar with former President Richard Nixonâ€™s environmental policy. They approached oil lobbyists about the need for climate change conversations. They handed out stickers to rising young Republican voters. â€œThe word â€˜Conservativeâ€™ is in â€˜conservation,â€™â€ said Aidan Shank, one member of the American Conservation Coalition, the environmental group that set up the booth. For years, the Republican Party has gotten a reputation for denying climate science and the urgency of global warming. Their statements about the environment usually focus on burning more fossil fuels, the biggest driver of climate change. But this year, for the first time in recent memory, conservatives had a climate showing at the Republican National Convention. The leadership of the American Conservation Coalition (ACC) flew to Milwaukee for a week of conversations around climate, conservation, and energy. They kept up efforts to win delegatesâ€™ attention and support, even as their party nominated former President Donald Trump, who doesnâ€™t acknowledge the full effects of human-caused climate change and has vowed to rescind many of President Bidenâ€™s climate-related investments. Young conservatives are likely to support Trump this November. Still, they want to see their party talk about climate and energy policy. They see potential for a Trump administration to prioritize domestic production of clean energy. Unlike their Democratic counterpartsâ€“and prevailing climate scienceâ€”they also still back oil and gas development. â€œWe can be hopeful. And our approach has always been to work with people where we can,â€ said Danielle Butcher Franz, CEO of ACC. She added: â€œWe really are using this RNC to introduce ourselves to the base, and to stakeholders, and to say there's a better way to do environmental policy.â€ Young conservatives hope to reframe the conversation On their first morning in Milwaukee, six members of ACC got ready at an Airbnb for their convention debut. Decked out with their American flag caps, brown Tevoca boots, American flag belt and button-up shirt with bison, they planned out their RNC reception event schedule: arrive at 1 pm, do a reception hosted by another group, and have time to visit, talk to dozens of people over five hours. ACC was an RNC sponsor, cementing its mark at the Republican gathering. It's considered a significant milestone for the group, which formed in 2017 during the first Trump administration. At its inception, it quickly attracted young politicos like Stephen Perkins, the 29-year-old chief operating officer of ACC. â€œI grew up going camping and with my dad and fishing and all that sort of stuff. And so we've always had an appreciation for the environment and the outdoors,â€ said Perkins, of the Texas places he grew up in and loved. â€œAs I got more involved in politics, the issues that I gravitated toward were the tougher ones.â€ Perkins likes to talk to fellow young conservatives about the impact of climate change on most policy issues. He recalled when one young Republican told him that he didnâ€™t care about climate â€” that he was more concerned about immigration. Perkins had an answer for him. â€œNot the only reason, but a big reason why people are coming here is many of them are climate refugees,â€ Perkins said of the explanation he gave about immigration â€œThere are places where whether it's flooding or extreme heat, they're coming here to escape that. And so there's actually a connection.â€ Generally, Republicans have not seen climate as their issue. And leaders, like Trump and Vance, have championed fossil fuel production over conservation and climate action. â€œHeâ€™s (Trump) not perfect. We certainly recognize that. He needs to talk about climate change,â€ Perkins said. â€œBut when you talk about seven years ago when ACC was started, you couldn't get Republican elected officials to even talk about climate change.â€ Some of that has evolved. During the first GOP debate, an ACC member asked presidential candidates running against Trump how they would ease fears that the GOP doesnâ€™t care about climate. There were few direct answers. Although climate is not a top issue for Republicans, i [t does rank higher on the list of policy priorities for younger Republican](https://www.npr.org/2023/08/25/1195566969/climate-change-made-it-in-the-gop-debate-some-young-republicans-say-thats-a-win)s. The steps are small but ACC hopes a younger generation of conservatives can reframe the conversation. One way of doing so was with the large booth at the convention. Most visitors were curious and generally supportive. They picked up stickers, and fliers and colored a large poster that spelled out the word â€œlegacy.â€ There was the occasional pushback â€” like an oil lobbyist who denied climate change. â€œApproaching every conversation with empathy is the first place to begin,â€ said Aidan Shank, who was staffing the ACC table. â€œThere's so many places where we can agree, and just assuming that the conversation revolves around finding those agreements, sometimes that's the most constructive way to create dialogue.â€ The leaders at ACC wanted to create the organization in order to facilitate the conversations Shank is having at the convention now. Like Perkins, Danielle Butcher Franz grew up in the outdoors. Raised in a more liberal family, she said she never thought of the environment as a partisan issue, until she started talking to others. â€œAs we would speak to our peers, we would notice over and over them saying things like, â€˜I'm conservative except on the environmentâ€™ or â€˜I want to support Democrats because of climate change,â€™â€ Butcher Franz said. Though she generally feels welcome in her conservative spaces, she at first had to fight stereotypes. â€œOn the right, you would sort of have this skepticism of, â€˜Are you really conservatives, or is this like a Trojan horse for big government solutions that we don't agree with?â€™ â€ Butcher Franz said, noting that she also pushes back against stereotypes about Republican interest in climate. â€œIt can be frustrating to have to constantly feel like you're in myth-busting mode, and you have to constantly dispel these preconceived notions that people have about what you believe and what you stand for,â€ Butcher Franz said. Republicans celebrate being at the convention â€” at all Later in the day, the group gathers inside the Mitchell Park Domes Horticulture Conservatory to host a reception with dozens of guests and to talk about energy innovation, and Republicansâ€™ long involvement with the environment. Mainly, they wanted to celebrate being at the convention. Nearly all the speakers acknowledged that this kind of convention presence was new and signals a turning tide. In remarks, ACC President Chris Barnard noted that he believed this was a historic event. â€œThis is the first time something like this has happened at a Republican convention â€” we have a conservative climate reception,â€ he proudly told the crowd. Talking with NPR, Barnard says he still feels like there is a stereotype that to care about climate or conservation is to be a Democrat. But he wants to see the GOP â€” even Trump and Vance â€” to take advantage of the issue. â€œIt's politically very popular,â€ Barnard said. â€œAnd so the first thing to say really is that for anyone in the Republican Party, that's not championing that message: That's really just a lost opportunity.â€ Barnard saw speaking to delegates and other 2024 candidates at the convention as a foot in the door. And he hopes ACCâ€™s conversations, the booth and receptions encourage them to address climate in their local races. â€œIt's important to talk to them and kind of equip them with the messaging and how they can talk about these issues,â€ Barnard said. â€œAnd hoping that there's a good opportunity to work with Republicans on important environmental and climate policies.â€ Copyright 2024 NPR

author: Jeremy Thomas
title: Corey Graves Reacts To Unprotected Chairshot to Jack Perry On AEW Dynamite
text: [wrestling](/wrestling/) / [News](/wrestling/category/News/) Corey Graves Reacts To Unprotected Chairshot to Jack Perry On AEW Dynamite Corey Graves wasnâ€™t a fan of Jack Perry taking an unprotected chairshot to the head on last nightâ€™s AEW Dynamite. The Blood & Guts match that main evented last nightâ€™s show saw Perry get handcuffed to the side of the cage, and at one point Mark Briscoe waffled him in the head with a chair. Graves, who retired from the ring due to concussion issues, posted to his Twitter account and wrote: â€œThis is not meant to sound judgmental, or incite â€˜us vs. themâ€™ or question anybodyâ€™s passion, or talent or intentions. This is just coming from a guy whose career ended from a few too many ACCIDENTAL headshots. The ART of this business is protecting ourselves and each other. Trust meâ€¦the gaps in memory are not worth it. I promise.â€ Graves has since deleted the tweet. Some fans online have defended the spot, arguing that the chair was gimmicked. You can see Gravesâ€™ tweet and a clip of the chair shot in the below tweet: In a now deleted tweet, Corey Graves seemingly responded to Jack Perry taking an unprotected chair shot to the head during the [#AEWBloodAndGuts]Match on [#AEWDynamite]on Wednesday. I couldnâ€™t agree more. ðŸ‘ I donâ€™t understand how people can argue/attack someone for being RIGHT. [pic.twitter.com/7EU5P3McDB] â€” PW Chronicle (@_PWChronicle) [July 25, 2024]

author: Staff Writer
title: Superviviente de CÃ¡ncer de PÃ¡ncreas da un Gran Salto
text:
Superviviente de CÃ¡ncer de PÃ¡ncreas da un Gran Salto
En 2014, Manuel GarcÃ­a, de 21 aÃ±os, decidiÃ³ dejar de lado el paracaidismo. Saltar desde aviones costaba mucho dinero, y su idea de empezar a practicar [BASE jumping](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BASE_jumping) (salto desde puentes o acantilados) tambiÃ©n tuvo que esperar. DespuÃ©s de 81 saltos, GarcÃ­a decidiÃ³ hacer una pausa hasta poder permitirse comprar su propio equipo.
Cinco aÃ±os despuÃ©s de hacer una pausa en el deporte, GarcÃ­a comenzÃ³ a sentir un dolor agudo en el abdomen, nÃ¡useas y una pÃ©rdida de peso severa. DespuÃ©s de que una ecografÃ­a revelara problemas en el hÃ­gado, ingresÃ³ a un hospital en la zona de Miami, donde le diagnosticaron cÃ¡ncer en etapa 4.
â€œFue el Viernes Santo,â€ recuerda. Al principio, no sabÃ­an quÃ© tipo de cÃ¡ncer tenÃ­a, pero vieron que se habÃ­a propagado al hÃ­gado. El Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center ofreciÃ³ un diagnÃ³stico el domingo de Pascua: era cÃ¡ncer pancreÃ¡tico metastÃ¡sico en etapa 4.
â€œTenÃ­a una masa del tamaÃ±o de una pelota de golf y mÃ¡s tumores de los que podÃ­an contar en el hÃ­gadoâ€, dice. El cÃ¡ncer tambiÃ©n se habÃ­a extendido a su columna vertebral, y tenÃ­a dos pequeÃ±os tumores cerebrales. â€œNo hace falta decir que era un desastre. No sabÃ­an si debÃ­a empezar quimioterapia o cuidados paliativos.â€
Enfrentando la mortalidad
En Sylvester, GarcÃ­a fue atendido por [Peter Hosein, M.D.](https://medicos.umiamihealth.org/provider/peter-joel-hosein/525839?unified=hosein&sort=relevance&tt=771e3194-1810-449f-9054-87c5a1dc840f&ut=f906b189-7d2f-4f2c-bd6e-d25012667ef4Ã—tamp=2024-11-06T20%3A16%3A01.786Z&from=search-list), director asociado de investigaciÃ³n clÃ­nica en el [Sylvester Pancreatic Cancer Research Institute](https://umiamihealth.org/es/sylvester-comprehensive-cancer-center/tratamientos-y-servicios/cancer-de-pancreas) . El cÃ¡ncer se habÃ­a propagado demasiado como para que la cirugÃ­a fuera una opciÃ³n, y ademÃ¡s habÃ­a preocupaciÃ³n de que GarcÃ­a estuviera demasiado dÃ©bil para soportar la quimioterapia. â€œEl Dr. Hosein dijo que lo Ãºnico que podÃ­a hacer era darme quimioterapia diluida al 25%â€, cuenta GarcÃ­a. â€œEsa era la Ãºnica oportunidad que nos quedabaâ€.
La quimioterapia diluida empezÃ³ a dar resultado. DespuÃ©s de tres meses, GarcÃ­a cambiÃ³ a inmunoterapia. â€œEstuve en inmunoterapia unos dos aÃ±osâ€, dice. â€œDe hecho, Â¡tuve mi primera tomografÃ­a limpia en la vÃ­spera de AÃ±o Nuevo, nueve meses despuÃ©s de empezar la inmunoterapia!â€ Unos meses despuÃ©s, tuvo una recaÃ­da. â€œNo fue gran cosaâ€, dice. â€œLa eliminaron con radiaciÃ³nâ€.
Mientras recibÃ­a tratamiento, GarcÃ­a volviÃ³ a pensar en su decisiÃ³n de pausar el paracaidismo. â€œTenÃ­a 26 aÃ±os, y me dijeron que estaba muriendo,â€ afirma.
Recuerdo haberle explicado a mi mejor amigo Chris: â€œSÃ© que no voy a morir; sÃ© que puedo vencer estoâ€.
â€“ Manuel GarcÃ­a
En mayo de 2020, a mitad de su tratamiento contra el cÃ¡ncer, obtuvo su primer paracaÃ­das. Dos aÃ±os despuÃ©s, empezÃ³ a practicar BASE jumping.
Hoy, a los 31 aÃ±os, GarcÃ­a lleva cinco aÃ±os libre de cÃ¡ncer. Trabaja en el negocio de su familia, representando a fabricantes de plomerÃ­a decorativa de alta gama. Y ha vuelto a lanzarse desde aviones, acantilados y puentes..
Actualmente cuenta con 575 saltos en paracaÃ­das y 50 de BASE jumping.
Encontrar apoyo
Cuando estuvo enfermo, GarcÃ­a encontrÃ³ un fuerte apoyo entre amigos y familiares.
TÃ­as, tÃ­os, primosâ€¦ todos los que formaban parte de su vida se unieron para darle fuerza y ayudarlo a mantenerse optimista. â€œFue difÃ­cil para mis padresâ€, dice, â€œa pesar de mi optimismo ingenuo y mi confianzaâ€.
Las personas que padecen cÃ¡ncer necesitan el amor y el apoyo de sus amigos, familiares y de la comunidad, afirma GarcÃ­a. â€œY tambiÃ©n tienes que ser tu propio defensor en tu cuidado mÃ©dico y encontrar el mejor lugar, el mejor doctor que tenga el tratamiento que necesitas.â€.
Fuera del trabajo, del paracaidismo y el BASE jumping, GarcÃ­a trabaja como voluntario para la[ American Cancer Society](https://www.cancer.org/), la [Seena Magowitz Foundation](https://seenamagowitzfoundation.org/) y el Programa de Adolescentes y JÃ³venes Adultos de Sylvester para sobrevivientes de cÃ¡ncer de entre 15 y 39 aÃ±os. Y sigue haciendo tiempo para saltar en paracaÃ­das.
â€œMis mÃ©dicos y mi familia me preguntan a menudo por quÃ©â€, comenta. â€œLa razÃ³n principal es que es algo que era muy importante para mÃ­ y que dejÃ© pendiente. Son mis esperanzas y sueÃ±os actuales. La casa, los niÃ±os, la familia y la hipoteca parecen estar bien, pero ahora mismo lo que quiero es volarâ€.
Louis Greenstein es colaborador del Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center.
